job_title: Population Health Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: - Great hours, strictly 9-5 and entirely remote with option to go to office in BMC campus whenever you want. - Amazing management who truly care about you and your career development. Genuinely the best mentorship I ever had, even after working at prestigious economic consulting / MBB before hand. - Great exposure to american healthcare system. Got to deal with hospital administrators, community health leaders, physicians, and state public health officials. - Feels like you are making a difference. Lots of projects help vulnerable groups like substance use disorder patients, houseless folks, and underserved racial minorities. - Genuinely lovely colleagues, most of whom have advanced degrees / lots of public health experience and can teach you a thing or two.
cons: - Pace of work can be too slow, since its after all a nonprofit organization with lots of internal bureaucracy. - The data analytics team often don't have the best tech / IT support. Have spent entire days on the phone with BMC's tech team trying to get equipment / authorization access. - Work can get boring after a while, since a large chunk of tasks involve the minutiae of analyzing healthcare claims data.

pros: When it comes to patient care, I have worked in multiple Boston area hospitals. Boston Medical Center walks the walk and talks the talk of caring for anyone and everyone. I believe it is the largest free-care hospital in New England. Spanish, Haitian, Cape Verde, Brazilian... if you name a place, we likely have a patient population from there as well as staff from there as well. We have an extensive phone interpreter program in case you only speak one, two or three languages. I have one co-worker who speaks 5 (FIVE!) languages! For that reason, there is a dedication through out the whole hospital that is palpable. And I see this at all levels: Nurses, MD's, housekeeping, admin staff.
cons:
Now this is a large institution and that always brings issues with communication, changes that nobody wants to make. There is also a strong sense of conforming to the rules and regs of the Joint Commision. And, while that is not a bad thing, it does mean that people and departments can be quite policy and procedure bound. Essentially, the hospital doesn't shy away from red tape. 
Also, because of the location near several homeless shelters and "methadone mile" you will see alot of drunks, addicts and homeless people. In the hospital and around the fringes of campus. Security does a good job, a really good job trying to keep everyone safe. 
Also, it is a union hospital. again, not a good or bad thing... just adds more red tape.
And there are exceptions to the wonderful caring attitudes that I mentioned before. People using phones to call long distance relatives, watching TV in waiting rooms.
And of course staffing. always need more staffing.

pros: Free medical insurance and accessible locations.
cons: Working at Boston Medical was not one of my favorite work experiences. I constantly felt micromanage and I address that issue with the union and never did anything to address the issue with management. There isn't a culture overall at the hospital and most clinics are always busy, which is great! but when you depend on management to complete your work is a disaster and you leave work stress and overworked. I constantly saw my coworkers stress levels very high and management did nothing about it. Also, we always were very short staff because people will quit within months leaving everyone with more extra work and constant covering. Management once told us that we needed to get out of minds that we were short staff and that we could do it all. Another thing that disappointed me was that management expected perfection and zero room for mistake,  but never did properly train us because they never seemed to have time. If you were doing mistakes management will never let you know but instead will arrange meeting with the union to put pressure and give you warnings about losing your job. There are many more other things about BMC that were beyond disappointment. During my one year of employment at BMC I saw about seven people quit our clinic and I also had to quit because the stress was getting to much.

pros: Its a diverse population with interesting medical cases.
cons: Inadequate leadership in nursing.  From the CEO, DON on down to even the staff on units.  Mismanagement of time on staff RNs part and management in general.  Each unit I floated to, the culture was complain first, overrate acuity.  DOH, JCAHO guidelines aren't followed properly or staff has no/limited knowledge of them.  As one reviewer said there is a unwillingness to change, however management needs to address staff more appropriately, as opposed to derogatory.  Lack of respect all around.  During my tenure multiple units have been closed or minimized but there is never a benefit to Nursing only to the management.  Time off is seemingly difficult as a great majority of staff have been there for years.  Layoffs, forced retirement began to a larger extent with  the current CEO.  Both campuses have unions that do not fight for staff when the need it.  multiple co workers, RNs tried repeatedly to contact MNA, with limited avail, regardless their situations were not helped in anyway that would justify union dues.  During my years there, there were multiple clashes with staff and patients.  Whether it was a socio-economical disparity or racial disparity can be argued (with both being correct answers)

pros:

cons:

pros: Good benefits and pay is generally higher than other hospitals I have found.
cons: Very political environment where good&motivated employees are often driven out -either by frustration over lack of appropriate response by management in regards to employees who do not do their job effectively, or by the general knowledge that going to HR about these issues garners no real change. There are people in Director roles that have been able to continue a pattern of grossly unprofessional behavior towards employees under them who do not agree to fall in line with questionable choices. Despite employees taking this information (with proof that spans years) to HR, the Director is still there, and employees are still suffering.

review_title: Still a good hospital, working on getting back to great.
pros:
Working with people who care about patients is still the biggest pro for this or any hospital. I find that is still the case at BMC. Most staff actually care about the patients and do whatever is feasible to provide quality care.
Good pay and benefits.
cons: As the market for healthcare is evolving more 'fat trimming' measures makes for strained relations with management in this big city hospital. Consolidation of assets makes business sense. 30 year RNs not ready to retire are faced with difficult choices. Existing staff can feel threatened. Some feel new RN's aren't having to work fair share of off shifts.

pros:
- The mission of the hospital is incredible and motivating (if you can drag your spirits out of the daily grind long enough remember you are part of something extremely important to your community)

- Admin positions pay well for the non-profit sector
cons: The mission unfortunately has not trickled down into the administrative corporate culture. While many  employees are wonderful, dedicated, hardworking, professional - many are the total opposite. It is such a huge organization with not enough oversight to keep people accountable for their behavior towards patients, coworkers, etc. It seems as though administrative staff are allowed to be rude and incompetent without risking their jobs - leading to low patient satisfaction and disgruntled employees.

pros: Learn to speed walk through the "Methadone Mile" from the parking garage to work!
cons: Worked in facilities dept.  Workers are henpecked and pushed to the limit.  Must look busy and be willing to do just about anything that they're ordered to do.  Management micromanages to the point of exhaustion.  Very cliquey place, and if you miss a beat they will come down on you with both feet.  Will tell you anything to get you into the fold and then it's a full court press to make you feel like you're being watched in every conceivable way.  They have a triple-check system of watching their workers with camera's all over the place.   Many unhappy workers there pretend to be happy while counting the days until retirement.  BTW: parking will set you back in excess of $225 a month!

review_title: I know suffer from chronic stress!!
pros: I begin as a medical assistant in "02" I've been promoted several times and work as a team coordinator. If you're union they'll pay for your college education; however you only can take 6 credits per semester. If you work for B.U. hospital side you can attend BU for free
cons: Since it is union based, as management, I've dealt with them a lot. I finally was able to get rid of 2 employees after 5 years of supervising them. Parking is a killer I pay $50 per week pre-tax. Maybe because the facility is located in the inner city the patients we serve are tough, but they need the help. Upper management is not that helpful; we are so short staff in the clinic my director decides to go to Mexico for a month.

review_title: positive and negative aspects to the job, but my co-workers make the place the best
pros: easy access from south of town,  there is on site parking , no weekends with 25 years of service, there is a lot of diversity of people and cultures there.  Large enough to do interesting cases but small enough so you still feel it is personable.
cons: difficulty with important contract issues,  lack of respect from upper management,  floating   We get charged, through payroll deductions for parking so if you are off for two weeks vacation you still have to pay for parking and you pay the same amount if you work two days or 5 days.  Could use nicer and more places to sit outside.

job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: The community of patients you serve deal with a lot of income inequality issues, so your work will be challenging though rewarding when you know you are giving help to people who, otherwise, have nowhere else to turn. A lot of staff, including physicians and nurses, have been working at BMC for YEARS. There may be some differences in approaches to things (mostly around technology), but they are also very committed to their work and it is obvious in all the best ways.
cons: I was there when we changed to a new Electronic Medical Record system hospital-wide which added a new level of stress to everyone's work flow. There also doesn't seem to be much support in terms of professional development or growth if you're not a medical provider. Some people become bitter or hopeless after dealing with tough patient issues and situations.

review_title: Most humane place I ever worked
job_title: Senior Grants Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Very supportive, collegial environment. Everyone there is super smart, motivated and mission-driven. Benefits and pay are excellent. The clinical work and research is world-class, and it's wonderful to be a part of such a powerful mission to provide top quality care to those most in need, regardless of ability to pay. A true beacon of excellence!
cons: Minimal flexibility on working hours and location unless you count working from home in the middle of the night (usually by choice, very rarely by necessity). Even being out of office for a couple of hours for recurring doctor's appointments was a bit frowned upon.

pros: The Unions are in place so the Employees have a voice. The hospital takes care of the patients that have no other place to go. They support the community with food pantries and other community out reach programs. Good medical care at almost half the cost of the other area hospitals.
cons: The hospital needs to advertise their services. They need to push quality doctors and services at  low costs for low overhead.  They need to follow up with the patients. They need something new, like visiting doctors program or something that the other hospitals are not doing.

job_title: Practice Services Representative in Boston, MA
pros: One of the best reasons to work at Boston Medical Center is helping patient. Must of the patient call confused about medication, insurance coverage, when is there next appointment. I could tell on their voice how confuse they were but by the time I was done helping them I can sense the relieve on their voices and the patient would thank me many time for helping the. Just that little part made my day knowing that I was able to put a smile on someones face and at the same time they felt relieve.
cons: The only down size that I can think of is the way the call center was set up, but they are working on making it more comfortable for employers.

review_title: Financial analyst - High turnover poor management
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: Lots of talented young professionals looking to build a career. Easy to learn systems and basic problem solving skills will provide quick mastery.
cons: Turnover is incredibly high across management and associates. The ones who stay are the ones causing most or all of the issues. Some management could be sincerely described as highly incompetent. The other half of management is the exact opposite and highly skilled. It's a mishmash of broken failing systems, horrible technology, massive roadblocks, and incompetent management stopped the talented people from making real changes.

pros: You are making a difference here. I love working with many of my co-workers. Despite complaints to the contrary, benefits are competitive with other major employers in the city.
cons: There is a large amount of disconnect or lack of empathy between senior management and rank-and-file staff. Employees have been asked to do more with far fewer resources over time. Changes are made unilaterally in the name of cost savings, at the cost of quality patient care. HR moves slowly, even by the standards of most major employers, and there is little to no support for those seeking advancement.

review_title: Everything is great except the lack of cleanliness
pros: Most of the other trainers are very friendly and some will go out of their way to help you if you need any help. The pay isn’t bad as well.
cons: There is so much disorganization in management decisions. The people and managers are nice though. The hospital is unbelievably filthy in regards to keeping facilities and computer equipment clean. We often feel the need to clean the computer areas before we use them. The chairs look like they have years of crap, germs and dust on them, it makes me itchy sitting in a lot of chairs located in the computer training rooms.

review_title: A Learning Experience within a Diverse Culturally Work Environment

review_title: HORRIBLE. Most abusive, demeaning, and unsupportive place I have ever worked
pros: none. The nurses are bullies and mean-spirited.
cons: I was promised 3-12 mos training for a specialty I had never worked in. Within 2 weeks on the job, I was told that I had to be independent in 2 weeks in a critical care unit. No support, constant berating & scolding, abusive, punitive and demeaning work environment. Nurses are horrible and mean-spirited towards new staff. Tried as hard as I could, then was fired after 2 months. None of the training as outlined was provided. I was relentlessly pimped by a control-freak chief who constant;y interrupted my work flow with this pimping while I was trying to make a plan for my patients for the day. Ridiculous. Pimping staff??? Disrupting my work flow? Outrageous.

pros: Great benefits package, FTE's receive 5 weeks off + holidays to start.  I can only speak for the few departments I've worked in and with, but the people are professional and competent, yet laid back.  My supervisors have all been great about the employee review process.  There has been a lot of opportunity to grow within the hospital.
cons: The location is terrible.  The hospital is not only a pain to get to, but the area itself is not exactly safe.  I don't like our HR department.  In my experience with the initial hire and internal transfer, the process was a bigger pain that it had to be.

review_title: The most underrated hospital in Boston, an amazing place to work
pros: The employees and the patients are the best reason to work at Boston Medical Center. At BMC you can really be yourself, and be fully accepted. People have great senses of humor, but are also brilliant and great at their jobs. The patient population is unbelievably unique. The other Boston hospitals have good patient populations as well, but nothing quite compares to the BMC population, which is made up of a mix of various underserved populations, as well as a variety of middle and upper class patients.
cons: Overshadowed in name by the Harvard hospitals, but probably should not be.

review_title: Great people, need to invest more in employees
pros: Coworkers are some of the smartest and most dedicated people you will ever meet. Definitely the best part of the  job and helped me learn and grow not only as an employee but a person.
cons: The organization... BMC needs to invest more in the professional development of its employees. Politics and a beaucratic, slow system get in the way of gettng things done. HR and IT are very unhelpful. My research team was able to hire new people in spite of delays from HR.

pros: my peers are wonderful to work with, my immediate boss is fair.
cons:
The Union, they don't support the membership.  They are not aware of upcoming management decisions that involved the laying off of a large number of nurses and ancelery staff.
The health care bill is taking it's toll on healthcare in Mass and BMC is no exception.

review_title: Boston Medical Center is a wonderful organization, but I did not have the best experience due to my immediate managers.
pros:
BMC has a great benefits package, including free health insurance.
Individuals who want to work with a safety net population will get to see all sorts of health issues not experienced in better facilities.
cons: BMC is on the precipice of collapse; it is broke and may trip its bond covenants because of the high rate of uninsured individuals who receive care here (BMC does not receive reimbursement from the state for these individuals, so it hemorrhages money in their treatment).

review_title: Great place to be a nurse
pros: great pay, benefits, patient load, matching 401k, teaching hospital so you have a lot of young MDs with lots of enthuesiasm
cons: very fast turnover in Nursing supervisors, once you achieved high salary you had target on your back. offerd overtime frequently by staffing office but made to feel like criminal by your nurse mgr

pros: I enjoyed the mission and diversity of the organization.
cons: The Hospital is a Unionized environment. Most of the time the Union is great to work with, but sometimes there are challenges related to process. I had a colleague who refused to follow the union policy. As we moved through the progressive action process, one of the steps was that the employee was given a 3-day leave, with pay, so that she could "decide" whether to comply with union policy. Other employees had to pick up the slack until the employee decided to follow the rules.

review_title: BMC is a Great Place to Work
job_title: Web Content Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Employees care about each other and see the importance of their role in the big picture. Just had a fun 5 year celebration and met so many others who love what they do. BMC has an annual survey for employees to provide input on their areas so they can retain great workers. The hospital is always implementing changes that continue to improve and expand patient services. A new campus expansion project is underway through 2017.
cons: Can't think of any at this time...

pros:
The employees are the hardest working people you will find.   They are dedicated to a mostly needy patient population.  
The benefits are good.
cons: BMC used to treat staff like family.  Now if you don't use your AIDET skills you're disciplined or terminated.  They let people go that know the history of BMC/University/BCH and are loyal and dedicated so they can hire employees that will just do the job and don't question them.

pros: The health benefits are pretty good and the mission of providing health care to all is admirable. The company does appear to make gestures toward addressing employee concerns.
cons: Upward mobility is difficult and their rules regarding salary increases (never more than 5% regardless of title change, role change, etc.) is unfair. Getting here on public transportation is frustrating, and many employees openly express their contempt for the workplace.

review_title: Not a bad place to start, but not something you'd want to stay for long term.

Management is a complete mess, constantly gossiping and playing favoritism but pretend they don't. 
Pretends to be a flexible workplace but in reality you're going to be thrown into plenty of shifts that you didn't sign up for.
Expect alot of in house drama like it's a kindergarten.

review_title: Staff unprofessional, doctors conceded. The pay for the number of hours worked & the amount of work is low.

cons: Low pay for the number of hours worked. There were many many times when I put in 10 hours of overtime in a week and was not paid for those extra hours . The staff are rude to each other. pros: Excellent supervisor, great co-workers, management really seems to care about providing a good working environment for employees, great benefits

review_title: Compassionate care, great place to grow.

cons: I really don't have anything bad to say. The population that Boston Medical Center works with is mostly low income and low levels of education, but everyone tries their best to help out of love, care, and compassion.

review_title: Not an easy place to work
pros: Exposure to a wide variety of medical situations that give you an experience you can't get just anywhere.
cons: Promotions often given to people who don't deserve it while others who work very hard don't get any notice. The comment of " that's just the way it is around here" seems to be the norm instead of trying to make things better.

review_title: Higher up fire those making the most $

review_title: Meaningful work, stable job, highest paying hospital
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: Been employed at several Boston-area hospitals during my career, and none compare to the base salary provided at BMC. Great colleagues, and leadership with clear financial goals. Proud of the work we do.
cons: Stable job, but the flipside of which comes with some stagnation. Limited opportunities for advancement; hired into current role with maybe one additional promotion, usually received after 3 years or with additional training (at BMC expense).

pros: Opportunity for growth. Medical staff is highly knowledgable and invested in their careers. Admin staff has the ability to join the union.

review_title: Ridiculous Place to Work For (Outpatient pharmacy)
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Boston, MA
pros:
- The pay is fair at this hospital compared to other hospitals.
- This hospital has good benefits.
- Some of the people who work here (most technicians), are fine
cons:
Let's get started......
- First of all, the only way to move up in this place is to be a two-faced person and report ANYTHING and EVERYTHING to management.
- Some technicians in this place will act as if they are cordial with you, friendly with you, care about you but behind closed doors, they will watch your every mistake in order to report you and move up in the "RANKS".
- This place is very unfair in terms of rules and regulations (starting January 1st, 2016, there is no grace period and you will be faced with disciplinary action if you are even 1 min late, they have a zero-tolerance cell phone policy that will make you face disciplinary action if IT IS CHARGING ON THE WALL OUTSIDE THE PHARMACY, AWAY FROM THE WORK STATIONS).
-There is so much tension in this place and people are stressed not because of the work load but because of the people such as the management team and the "cronies" of the management team. I made the huge mistake of trusting my co-workers in beliefs that we can work in accordance as a team but you can trust nobody.
- Career advancement and Opportunities are a 50/50 in this place as few people in this place have made it out and made it to better positions and got promoted but those very few individuals were the cronies that told on other and made life like h**l for the rest of us technicians.
-You can work your butt off and be the hardest worker in this place but if you are not liked or favored by anybody in the management team, then you are not going anywhere
